org.dyn4j.collision.broadphase

Class SapTree<E extends Collidable>

  • java.lang.Object
    • org.dyn4j.collision.broadphase.AbstractAABBDetector<E>
      • org.dyn4j.collision.broadphase.SapTree<E>
  • Type Parameters:
    E - the Collidable type
    All Implemented Interfaces:
    BroadphaseDetector<E>

    public class SapTree<E extends Collidable>
extends AbstractAABBDetector<E>
implements BroadphaseDetector<E>
    Implementation of the Sweep and Prune broad-phase collision detection algorithm.

    This implementation maintains a red-black tree of Collidables where each update will reposition the respective Collidable in the tree.

    Projects all Collidables on both the x and y axes and performs overlap checks on all the projections to test for possible collisions (AABB tests).

    The overlap checks are performed faster when the Intervals created by the projections are sorted by their minimum value. Doing so will allow the detector to ignore any projections after the first Interval that does not overlap.

    If a Collidable is made up of more than one Shape and the Shapes are not connected, this detection algorithm may cause false hits. For example, if your Collidable consists of the following geometry: (the line below the Shapes is the projection that will be used for the broad-phase) 

     +--------+     +--------+  |
 | body1  |     | body1  |  |
 | shape1 |     | shape2 |  | y-axis projection
 |        |     |        |  |
 +--------+     +--------+  |
 
 -------------------------
     x-axis projection
    So if following configuration is encountered it will generate a hit: 
                 +--------+               |
 +--------+  | body2  |  +--------+   | |
 | body1  |  | shape1 |  | body1  |   | |
 | shape1 |  |        |  | shape2 |   | | y-axis projection
 |        |  |        |  |        |   | |
 +--------+  |        |  +--------+   | |
             +--------+               |
 
             ----------
 ----------------------------------
         x-axis projection
    These cases are OK since the NarrowphaseDetectors will handle these cases. However, allowing this causes more work for the NarrowphaseDetectors whose algorithms are more complex. These situations should be avoided for maximum performance.
    Since:
    1.0.0
    Version:
    3.1.5
    Author:
    William Bittle
